Now, with regard to CPP apps there is good news and bad news..
 
 The GOOD news is that CPP files, classes etc work, the bad news is that 'iostream' and the C++ headers don't work. Yes I have integrated them, and can compile them, and it works, but when you run it, it just seg faults.. :-(
 
 SO - you can use cpp files, but you need to stick with the standard C header files. When I fix it, I'll add it.
 
 (ps If anyone doea get it working, please let me know!)
 
 Let's cd into the directory
 
 # cd ~/system/src/c_examples/cpphello/
 
 There is rect.cpp and the Makefile. Check out the cpp file :
 
 # cat rect.cpp
 
 Start by compiling with
 
 # terminal-g++ -o rect rect.cpp
 
 You now have an executable 'rect' in this folder.
 
 Now let's use the Makefile. Check it out to see what it does..
 
 # cat Makefile
 
 # make clean
 
 # make
 
 (normally just 'make' will do..)
 
 Now - another new feature is the TAGLIST vim plugin. This is a very handy plugin that shows a breakdown of the classes, variables in a file.
 
 I have set it to toggle On/Off with 'F3' in your ~/.vimrc file. You can edit the width and other properties there.
 
 Just run 'vim rect.cpp' or 'terminalide', and press F3 to see it in action.
 
 Also - you now have 'ctags', a requirement of taglist. Check Google, for how to best use this for you..
 
 Next a c library..
